title: Personal Investing: A Monthly Analysis --- Financial Flashback: A look back at Wall Street Journal headlines from this month
text:
The malfeasance involved other banks, including JPMorgan Chase, NatWest, Deutsche Bank and Citigroup. Together bankers manipulated a key interest rate known as the London interbank offered rate (Libor) by recording incorrect borrowing costs.

That might seem like a technical problem, but $300 trillion of global financial contracts relied on these Libor rates, including complex derivatives as well as home mortgages and auto loans.

"Some counterparties were paying too much on their loans, others too little," says Pete Earle, an economist at the American Institute for Economic Research.

However, Mr. Earle isn't surprised, given previous dodgy Wall Street antics, including Treasury bond rigging and timing mutual-fund sales. "Whenever a group of large financial institutions get together a 'pick price,' you are asking for trouble," he says.

The scandal prompted the development of a new benchmark, SOFR, the secured overnight financing rate, which will be transparent based on observed transactions. By June 2023, SOFR should have wholly replaced Libor.
